revision.comment: nope, there's no reference for this. (It's the one other religion that protestant fundamentalists tolerate)
revision.text:
{{unreliable sources|date=October 2016}} [[File:This Was Your Life.gif|thumb|''This Was Your Life!'' is a Chick tract that was translated in over 100 languages and is described by Chick Publications as its most popular title<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.chick.com/catalog/assortments/0915.asp | title=English Tract Assortment Pack | publisher=Chick Tracts | accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref>]] '''Chick tracts''' are short [[Evangelicalism|evangelical]] [[gospel]] [[tract (literature)|tracts]], originally created and published by American publisher and religious cartoonist [[Jack Chick]]. Since his death, his company (Chick Publications) has continued to print new tracts using other authors working for the company.
Although many of Chick's tracts express views that are generally accepted within [[Christian theology]], several tracts have expressed controversial viewpoints. Most notably, Chick tracts were known for expressing strongly [[Anti-Catholicism|anti-Catholic views]], as well as his criticisms of other religions including Islam and [[Mormonism]].
==Chick Publications== Chick Publications produces and markets the Chick tracts, along with other comic books, books, and posters.<ref>Chapman, Roger (2010) ''Culture Wars: an Encyclopedia of Issues, Viewpoints, and Voices'', Volume 1 M E Sharpe, p. 84</ref> Chick Publications has its headquarters in [[Rancho Cucamonga, California|Rancho Cucamonga]]<ref name="Company Profile:Chi">{{cite web | title=Company Profile:Chick Publications, Inc | publisher=Dun and Bradstreet, Inc. | year=2007 | url =http://www.manta.com/coms2/dnbcompany_c4x0hn | accessdate=2008-02-25}}</ref> and has an [[Ontario, California]] mailing address.
The company estimates it has printed over 800 million tracts during its first 50 years of business. On its website they note that "Our ministry is primarily publishing the gospel tracts of Jack T. Chick, but we do occasionally publish a manuscript in book form."<ref name="FAQ: Will Chick Pu">{{cite web | title=FAQ: Will Chick Publications publish my book? | publisher= Chick Publications, Inc. | date=1984–2008 | url =http://www.chick.com/information/general/chickinfo.asp#publish | accessdate=2008-02-25}}</ref> They state that if the content "educates Christians in one of the areas for which we have a tract, we would love to see it" and cite several examples; the online store lists nearly a dozen book categories.<ref name="FAQ: Will Chick Pu"/>
As of January 2015, Chick Publications had produced over 250 different titles, about 100 of which are still in print, and are available in over 100 languages.<ref>{{cite web | title=ChickComics.com: The Jack Chick Museum of Fine Art | publisher= The Chick Tract Collector's Club; Not affiliated with Jack T Chick, LLC | date=2015 | url =http://www.monsterwax.com/chick.html | accessdate=2015-03-18}}</ref>
==Format and storylines== The tracts themselves are approximately three inches high by five inches wide in dimension, and approximately twenty pages in length.<ref>Bivins (2008) p. 41</ref> The material is written in [[comic book]] format, with the front panel featuring the title of the tract and the inside back panel devoted to a standard [[sinner's prayer]]. The back cover of the tract contains a blank space for churches to stamp their name and address; Chick Publications is willing to print custom back covers, but at least 10,000 tracts must be ordered.
The storyline commonly features at least one Christian person and one or more "non-Christians". Depending on the storyline the "non-Christian" may be 1) a stereotypical "wicked person" (such as a criminal; an example being the eponymous character of the tract ''Bad Bob!''),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chick.com/reading/tracts/0021/0021_01.asp |title=Bad Bob! |publisher=Chick.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-02}}</ref> 2) a member of a "false religion" (as Chick defines such; an example being the Mormon missionaries from ''The Visitors''),<ref name="The Visitors">{{cite comic|url=http://www.chick.com/reading/tracts/0061/0061_01.asp|title=The Visitors|date=1984|writer=Jack Chick}}</ref> and/or 3) a "moral person" depending on "good works" to gain eventual entrance to Heaven (as opposed to salvation through Jesus Christ; an example is the marshal in ''Gun Slinger'').<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chick.com/reading/tracts/0037/0037_01.asp |title=Gun Slinger |publisher=Chick.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-02}}</ref> In these storylines, the Christian attempts to convert the non-Christian to [[Christianity]] (and may also feature a contrast where another character, often the "moral person", does not), with the convert receiving entry into [[heaven]], while the person rejecting the message is [[damnation|condemned]] to [[hell]]. The endings may feature a recycled scene in which [[Jesus|Jesus Christ]] (portrayed as a giant, glowing, faceless figure sitting on a throne) condemns or welcomes a character, an angel taking the believer to Heaven, and/or the non-believer meeting demons upon his/her arrival to Hell.
==Themes==
Chick tracts end with a suggested prayer for the reader to pray to accept [[Jesus Christ]]. In most of these tracts it is a standard [[sinner's prayer]] for [[salvation]]. In the tracts dealing with "false religions", the prayer includes a clause to reject these religions. Included with the prayer are directions for converting to Christianity, which is also repeated on the inside back panel along with steps to take should the reader convert to Christianity.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.catholic.com/documents/the-nightmare-world-of-jack-t-chick |title=The Nightmare World of Jack T. Chick | Catholic Answers |publisher=Catholic.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140108154607/http://www.catholic.com/documents/the-nightmare-world-of-jack-t-chick |archivedate=2014-01-08 |df= }}</ref>
''Strips, Toons, and Bluesies'', written by Douglas Bevan Dowd and [[Todd Hignite]], stated that "it's safe to assume Chick saw at least some" [[Tijuana bible]]s since the books and, according to Dowd and Hignite, Chick tracts were "strikingly similar" to Tijuana bibles; like Tijuana bibles the tracts mostly targeted youth of lower socioeconomic classes and "were loaded with stereotypes". The book stated that Chick tracts contained "way-out, wild" portrayals of recreational drug usage and portrayed "the sexual revolution". In addition the comics included supernatural elements, occult rituals, torture, and cannibalism.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Dowd, Douglas Bevan |author2=Todd Hignite|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TjzlxyfWbxwC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_summary_r&cad=0#PPA40,M1|title=Strips, Toons, and Bluesies|publisher=[[Princeton Architectural Press]]|year=2006|page=40}}</ref>
==Controversies==
===Anti-Catholicism=== [[Catholic Church|Catholicism]] is a frequent target of Chick tracts and other writings. No fewer than twenty of the tracts are devoted to Catholicism, including ''Are Roman Catholics Christians?''<ref>{{cite comic|url=http://www.chick.com/reading/tracts/0071/0071_01.asp|title=Are Roman Catholics Christians?|date=1985|writer=Jack Chick}}</ref> (arguing that they are not), ''The Death Cookie''<ref>{{cite comic|url=http://www.chick.com/reading/tracts/0074/0074_01.asp|title=The Death Cookie|date=1988|writer=Jack Chick}}</ref> (a polemic against the Catholic [[Eucharist]]), and ''Why is Mary Crying?''<ref>{{cite comic|url=http://www.chick.com/reading/tracts/0040/0040_01.asp|title=Why is Mary Crying?|date=1987|writer=Jack Chick}}</ref> (arguing that Mary does not support the [[Veneration of Mary in the Catholic Church|veneration]] Catholicism gives her).<ref name="akin">{{cite book |title= The Nightmare World of Jack Chick |last= Akin |first= Jimmy |authorlink= Jimmy Akin |year= 2008 |location= San Diego |publisher= [[Catholic Answers]] }}</ref>
Elsewhere, Chick, defended the controversial [[Alberto Rivera (activist)|Alberto Rivera]] in at least one book<ref>{{cite book|url=http://www.chick.com/catalog/books/0199.asp|title=Is Alberto For Real?|author=Sidney Hunter|isbn=9780937958292}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chick.com/catalog/comiclist.asp#alberto |title=The compelling testimony of Alberto Rivera, a former Jesuit priest |publisher=Chick.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-21}}</ref> and in an entire series of six full-length comics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chick.com/catalog/comiclist.asp#alberto |title=Comic List |publisher=Chick.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-02}}</ref> Chick also asserted that the Catholic Church, in a grand conspiracy, created [[Islam]], [[Communism]], [[Nazism]], and [[Freemasonry]].<ref>{{cite comic|url=http://www.chick.com/reading/tracts/1077/1077_01.asp|title=Mama's Girls|date=2012|writer=Jack Chick}}</ref> In ''The New Anti-Catholicism'',<ref>{{cite book | last = Jenkins | first = Philip |authorlink=Philip Jenkins| title = The New Anti-Catholicism | publisher = Oxford University Press, USA | location = City | year = 2004 | isbn = 978-0-19-517604-9| page=24}}</ref> religious historian [[Philip Jenkins]] describes Chick tracts as promulgating "bizarre allegations of Catholic conspiracy and sexual hypocrisy" to perpetuate "[[anti-papal]] and anti-Catholic mythologies". Michael Ian Borer, a sociology professor of [[Furman University]] at the time, described Chick's strong anti-Catholic themes in a 2007 [[American Sociological Association]] presentation<ref>Borer, Michael. (2007) "Drawing Religious Battle Lines: The “Culture Wars Work” of Jack Chick’s Anti-Catholic Cartoons"[http://www.allacademic.com/meta/p181814_index.html "Drawing Religious Battle Lines: The “Culture Wars Work” of Jack Chick’s Anti-Catholic Cartoons"] paper presented at the annual meeting of the American Sociological Association, New York, New York City, Aug 11, 2007</ref> and in a peer reviewed article the next year in ''Religion and American Culture''.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Borer | first = Michael Ian | author-link = | last2 = Murphree | first2 = Adam | author2-link = | title = Framing Catholicism: Jack Chick's Anti-Catholic Cartoons and the Flexible Boundaries of the Culture Wars | journal = [[Religion and American Culture]] | volume = 18 | issue = 1 | pages = 95–112 |date= Winter 2008 | url = | doi=10.1525/rac.2008.18.1.95 }}</ref>
''[[Catholic Answers]]'' published a response to the claims of Chick Publications against Roman Catholics and a criticism of Chick Tracts in general called ''The Nightmare World of Jack T. Chick'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://catholic.com/library/sr_chick_tracts.asp |title=The Nightmare World of Jack T. Chick |publisher=Web.archive.org |date= |accessdate=2014-05-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110904055234/http://www.catholic.com/library/sr_chick_tracts.asp |archivedate=September 4, 2011 }}</ref> detailing the inaccuracies, factual errors, and how a "typical tactic in Chick tracts is to portray Catholics as being unpleasant or revolting in various ways".
===Anti-homosexuality=== Chick tracts are unequivocal and explicit in their opposition to [[homosexuality]], and repeatedly employ two anti-homosexual themes: *the belief that God hates [[homosexuality]] and considers it to be sinful, and *the true nature of homosexuality is revealed in the Christian interpretation of the biblical [[Sodom and Gomorrah]] story.
According to Cynthia Burack, Chick's earliest anti-homosexuality tract, ''The Gay Blade''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chick.com/reading/tracts/0084/0084_01.asp |title=The Gay Blade |publisher=Chick.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-02}}</ref> (originally written in 1972, revised in 1984 and now out-of-print except by special order), borrowed several of its frames from a 1971 ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'' magazine photo-essay on the [[Gay Liberation]] movement, but with the images altered to make the gay men look more dissolute or stereotypically feminized.<ref>{{cite book | last = Burack | first = Cynthia | title = Sin, Sex, and Democracy | publisher = State University of New York Press | location = Albany | year = 2008 | isbn = 0-7914-7405-4 |pages=33–66}}</ref>
===Anti-evolution=== {{Redirect|Big Daddy?||Big Daddy (disambiguation){{!}}Big Daddy}} {{further|Evidence of common descent}} Chick published several [[Objections to evolution|anti-evolution]] tracts, but ''Big Daddy?''<ref name="Big Daddy">{{cite web|url=http://www.chick.com/reading/tracts/0055/0055_01.asp |title=Big Daddy? |publisher=Chick.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-02}}</ref> remains "the most widely distributed anti-evolution booklet in history".<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Moore | first1 = Randy | last2 = Decker | first2 = Mark D. |title = More than Darwin: an Encyclopedia of the People and Places of the Evolution-Creationism Controversy | publisher = Greenwood Press | year = 2008 | isbn = 978-0-313-34155-7 |page=56}}</ref>
Critics point out that the ''Big Daddy?'' tract mainly uses [[Kent Hovind]] as a reference, despite the fact that Hovind has no degrees from accredited institutions in the relevant fields, that the thesis referred to is considered to be of very poor quality, and that his claims are at odds with the published statements of experts in the field.<ref>{{cite web | last =Vickers | first = Brett | title = Some Questionable Creationist Credentials | year = 1998 | url = http://www.talkorigins.org/faqs/credentials.html | accessdate = June 24, 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last =Bartelt, Ph.D. | first = Foley | title = The Dissertation Kent Hovind Doesn't Want You to Read | year = 2001 | url = http://home.austarnet.com.au/stear/bartelt_dissertation_on_hovind_thesis.htm | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070718063636/http://home.austarnet.com.au/stear/bartelt_dissertation_on_hovind_thesis.htm |archivedate = 2007-07-18 | accessdate = June 24, 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last =Foley | first = Jim | title = Fossil Hominids: Big Daddy? | publisher = talkorigins.org | date = August 31, 2001 | url = http://www.talkorigins.org/faqs/homs/bigdaddy.html | accessdate = June 24, 2009}}</ref><ref name="fowler">{{cite book | last = Fowler | first = Robert B. | title = The World of Jack T. Chick | year = 2001 | publisher = Last Gasp | pages= 2–10 | ISBN = 0-86719-512-6}}</ref>
''Big Daddy?'' is presented in the 2007 book ''Evolution: What the Fossils Say and Why it Matters'' as a "typical of the genre" example of just how "misleading and dishonest" [[Creationism|creationist]] presentations are. The examples of the "deceptive and misleading" distortions, misrepresentation, and fabrications presented in that work regarding ''Big Daddy?'' are "[[Nebraska Man]]" (the misinterpretation of which was corrected after only a year and its existence was debated from the beginning<ref>Wolf, John; James S. Mellett (1985) [http://www.talkorigins.org/faqs/homs/wolfmellett.html "The role of "Nebraska man" in the creation-evolution debate"] ''Creation/Evolution'' 16:31-43, National Center for Science Education</ref>), "[[New Guinea Man]]" (which is actually ''Homo sapiens''), and the implication "[[Cro-Magnon]]" man was viewed as different from ''[[Homo sapiens]]''.<ref>{{Cite book | last = Prothero | first = Donald R. | authorlink = | last2=Buell | first2= Carl Dennis | title = Evolution: What the Fossils Say and Why It Matters | publisher = Columbia University Press | year = 2007 | pages = 334–335 | isbn = 0-231-13962-4}}</ref>
===Views on Satanism and Satanic influence=== [[File:Nervous Witch 20.png|350px|thumb|A page from ''"The Nervous Witch"'', a Chick tract depicting the purportedly occult dangers of the ''[[Harry Potter]]'' series.]] The concept of malign influences led to the theme of [[spiritual warfare]] being frequently portrayed in the tracts. Chick considered all forms of [[witchcraft]] to be demonic, regardless of whether it was "white witchcraft" (i.e. purportedly using such gifts for good) or "black witchcraft" (i.e. purportedly using such gifts for evil). ''Gladys''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chick.com/reading/tracts/5017/5017_01.asp |title=Gladys |publisher=Chick.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-02}}</ref> is an example of one of Chick's tracts on this issue. Consistent with his views on demonic influence, Chick also considered [[Halloween]] to be "the devil's holiday" and opposed Christians celebrating it, with one notable exception – Chick did not oppose Christians engaging in the traditional Halloween custom of passing out candy to neighborhood children, considering it to be an opportunity to present the Gospel message via his tracts.<ref>Chick portrayed this dramatically in the tract ''The Little Princess'' (http://www.chick.com/reading/tracts/0063/0063_01.asp), the story of a terminally-ill young girl who receives a Chick tract from her neighbors on Halloween, accepts Christ and has the neighbors share the Gospel with her family, before dying later that night.</ref>
Based on Chick's views on Satanism and [[Satan]]ic influence, ''Catholic Answers'' states that "Chick portrays a world full of paranoia and conspiracy where nothing is what it seems and nearly everything is a Satanic plot to lead people to hell."<ref>{{cite web | title = The Nightmare World of Jack T. Chick | date = | year = | url = http://www.catholic.com/library/sr_chick_tracts.asp | accessdate = July 31, 2010 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110904055234/http://www.catholic.com/library/sr_chick_tracts.asp | archivedate = September 4, 2011 | df = }} </ref><ref name="Hodapp, 2008 105">{{Cite book | last = Hodapp | first = Christopher | author-link = | last2 = Von Kannon | first2 = Alice | author2-link = | title = Conspiracy Theories & Secret Societies For Dummies | publisher = For Dummies | year = 2008 | page = 105 | isbn = 0-470-18408-6}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book | last = Camp | first = Gregory S. | title = Selling fear: Conspiracy Theories and End-Times Paranoia | publisher = Baker Pub Group | year = 1997 | page = 189 | isbn = 0-8010-5721-3}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book | last = Lewis | first = James R. | title = Satanism Today: an Encyclopedia of Religion, Folklore, and Popular Culture | publisher = ABC-CLIO | year = 2001 | page = 46 | isbn = 978-1-57607-292-9}}</ref>
The tracts' claims about conspiracies are based in large part on the testimony of people who claim to have been members of these groups before converting to [[Evangelicalism|Evangelical]] Christianity, most prominently [[Alberto Rivera (activist)|Alberto Rivera]] and William Schnoebelen. Many of Chick's critics consider these sources to be frauds or [[fantasy|fantasists]].<ref name="fowler" /> One such case was "The Prophet"<ref name=Prophet>{{cite comic | writer = Jack Chick | title = The Prophet | publisher = Chick Publications | volume = 1 | issue = 6 | date = 1988 | url = http://www.chick.com/reading/comics/0117/theprophetindex.asp}}</ref> where the fantastic tale related by Rivera of how the papacy helped start [[Islam]] turned out to have no basis in reality.<ref name="Hodapp, 2008 105"/>
==Parodies and popular culture==
===In film=== * A live-action film [[Dark Dungeons (film)|''Dark Dungeons'']], based on the Chick tract of the same name that warns against the supposed evil influence of ''[[Dungeons and Dragons]]'', was released in August 2014. Producer JR Ralls was given the rights to the tract for free after contacting Chick.<ref>{{cite web|author=Rachel Edidin |url=https://www.wired.com/2014/05/dark-dungeons-movie/ |title=A Fearmongering Anti-RPG Comic Gets the Film Adaptation It Deserves | Underwire |publisher=WIRED |date= |accessdate=2014-05-21}}</ref>
===In print=== Some [[cartoonist]]s have published [[parodies]] that mimic Chick tracts' familiar layout and narrative conventions. Examples include:
* ''Devil Doll?'' by [[Daniel Clowes]], ''Antlers of the Damned'''<ref>{{cite web | url=<!--removed link to site (now a porn site) that tries to install something on visitors' machines.--> | title=Antlers Of The Damned | year= | publisher=The Jack T. Chick Parody Archive | author=Thrasher, Adam }}</ref> by [[Space Moose|Adam Thrasher]], ''Jesus Delivers!'' by [[Jim Woodring]] and David Lasky, ''Demonic Deviltry'' by "Dr. Robert Ramos" (actually [[Justin Achilli]] of [[White Wolf Game Studios]]), ''Ploy to the World?'' by Chrissy Spallone, and ''A Patriarchy's Nightmare'' by Keith Mayerson. * Issue #2 of Daniel K. Raeburn's [[zine]] ''[[The Imp (zine)|The Imp]]'', which consists of a lengthy [[essay]] on Jack T. Chick's work and a [[concordance (publishing)|concordance]] of terms and concepts used in his comics, has dimensions and covers that imitate a Chick tract. * Two parodies by Jack C. Trick, LLC and published by Trick Publications titled ''Chemical Salvation?'' (2006)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.erowid.org/chemicals/lsd/lsd_humor_chick_parody1.pdf |title=Chemical Salvation? |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2014-05-21}}</ref> and ''ADAM & EVIL?!'' (2007)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.erowid.org/chemicals/mdma/mdma_humor_chick_parody1.pdf |title=ADAM & EVIL?! for Web |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2014-05-21}}</ref> tell the history of [[LSD]] and [[MDMA]]. The LSD Trick tract, which was released on Albert Hofmann's 100th birthday and was partially reprinted in a recent biography of the inventor of LSD,<ref>{{cite book|title=Mystic Chemist: The Life of Albert Hofmann and His Discovery of LSD|year=2013|publisher=Synergetic Press|location=Santa Fe, NM|isbn=978-0-907791-46-1|page=244|author=Dieter Hagenbach|edition=First English|author2=Lucius Werthmüller|author3=Stanislav Grof|language=}}</ref> also appeared in a Japanese translation.<ref>http://www.erowid.org/chemicals/lsd/lsd_humor_chick_parody2.pdf</ref> * ''The Religious Experience of Philip K. Dick'' by cartoonist [[Robert Crumb]], published in ''[[Weirdo (magazine)|Weirdo]]'' magazine in 1986, parodies the style of a Chick tract comic sequence. * A parody entitled ''The Collector'' was drawn by cartoonist Hal Robins and included in chapter 13 of ''The Art of Jack T. Chick'' by Kurt Kuersteiner (2004, Schiffer Publishing, Ltd.). * The first edition of the Season 1 Blu-ray of the animated comedy show ''[[Rick and Morty]]'' came with a print version of ''The Good Morty'', a parody of Chick's work which also appears in Season 1 Episode 10 titled "Close Encounters of the Rick Kind." The comic is written by Justin Roiland & Ryan Ridley and illustrated by Erica Hayes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://spinoff.comicbookresources.com/2014/08/15/sdcc-rick-and-morty-creators-and-cast-tease-a-more-intergalactic-season-2/|title=SDCC - 'Rick and Morty' Creators and Cast Tease a 'More Intergalactic' Season 2|date=15 August 2014|website=comicbookresources.com|accessdate=16 May 2017}}</ref>
==Criticism== The [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] has designated Chick Publications as an active [[hate group]].<ref name="Active U.S. Hate">{{cite web | title=Active General Hate Groups | publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]] | url=http://www.splcenter.org/node/105/activegroups | accessdate=2011-01-13}}</ref> The group was listed due to its strong anti-Catholic, anti-Muslim, and anti-homosexual rhetoric.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.splcenter.org/blog/2011/11/02/pastor-apologizes-for-hate-filled-halloween-hand-out/|title=Pastor Apologizes For Hate-filled Halloween Hand-out|website=splcenter.org|accessdate=16 May 2017}}</ref> Chick's views on homosexuality have angered gay activists since his first tract on the subject in 1972 (''The Gay Blade'' tract warned of a gay agenda to push for same sex marriage and urged homosexuals to repent so they could make it into heaven).
Chick's critics (such as [[talk.origins]], [[Hindu American Foundation]], and [[Catholic Answers]]) have accused him of misrepresentation.
The [[Hindu American Foundation]] put out an electronic PDF paper called "Hyperlink to [[Hinduphobia]]: Online Hatred, Extremism and Bigotry Against [[Hindus]]"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hinduamericanfoundation.org/pdf/hate_report_2007.pdf |title=Hyperlink to Hinduphobia: Online Hatred, Extremism and Bigotry Against Hindus |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2014-05-21}}</ref> which contains a section on Chick's site; the paper ends with the statement "Chick Publications promotes hatred not just against Hindus, but also towards Muslims, Catholics, and others as is evidenced by the following titles of their tracts: 'Last Rites – When this Catholic dies, he learns that his church couldn't save him';<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chick.com/reading/tracts/0082/0082_01.asp |title=Last Rites |publisher=Chick.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-21}}</ref> 'The Little Bride – Protect children against being recruited as Muslims. Li'l Susy explains that only Jesus can save them';<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chick.com/reading/tracts/1054/1054_01.asp |title=English "The Little Bride" |publisher=Chick.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-21}}</ref> and 'Allah Had No Son – The Allah of Islam is not the God of creation{{'"}} (in both these anti-Islamic tracts Allah is [[Allah as Moon-god|revealed to be a pagan moon god]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chick.com/reading/tracts/0042/0042_01.asp |title=Allah Had No Son |publisher=Chick.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-21}}</ref>
The content of ''That Crazy Guy!''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chick.com/reading/tracts/0090/0090_01.asp |title=That Crazy Guy |publisher=Chick.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-02}}</ref> was changed after the rise of the [[HIV/AIDS|AIDS]] crisis (the tract was originally about [[herpes]]).<ref>{{cite web | last = Monsterwax | title = Jack T. Chick's Museum of Fine Art REVIEW WING | year = 2000 | url = http://www.monsterwax.com/chickreviews.html | accessdate = June 24, 2009}}</ref> Also, the ending to ''The Poor Little Witch''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chick.com/reading/tracts/0064/0064_01.asp |title=The Poor Little Witch |publisher=Chick.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-02}}</ref> (in which a little girl is murdered by Satanists after forsaking [[occultism]] and converting to fundamentalist Christianity) was changed because the [[urban myth]] which states that "every year in the U.S. at least 40,000 people ... are murdered in witchcraft ceremonies" (about twice the entire reported homicide rate for the U.S.) turned out to be false and was removed from the tract.<ref>[http://www.ojp.usdoj.gov/bjs/homicide/tables/totalstab.htm Homicide victimization, 1950-2005] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060929071718/http://www.ojp.usdoj.gov/bjs/homicide/tables/totalstab.htm |date=2006-09-29 }}, [[United States Bureau of Justice Statistics]], [[United States Department of Justice]], July 11, 2007</ref> Chick Publications depicts [[Paganism]] and [[Paganism (contemporary)|Neo-Paganism]] as forms of [[Satanism]], a position Neo-Pagans and other observers strongly dispute.
The Chick Publications website is [[Censorship in Singapore|blocked in Singapore]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.trevvy.com/scoops/article.php?a_id=348|title= Homophobic Evangelical Comics, Now Available in Singapore!|author=Tim|work=[[Trevvy]]|date=June 3, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717100458/http://www.trevvy.com/scoops/article.php?a_id=348|archivedate=July 17, 2011}}</ref> In December 2008, a Singaporean couple was charged with [[sedition]] for distributing the Chick tracts ''The Little Bride'' and ''Who Is Allah?'', said to "promote feelings of ill-will and hostility between Christians and Muslims in Singapore".<ref>{{cite web | last = Chong | first = Elena | title = Couple on sedition trial | publisher = Straits Times | date = December 4, 2008 | url = http://www.straitstimes.com/Breaking%2BNews/Singapore/Story/STIStory_310229.html | accessdate = June 24, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = Chong | first = Elena | title = No ill will intended | publisher = Aquarian Tabernacle Church | date = December 6, 2008 | url = http://www.straitstimes.com/Breaking%2BNews/Singapore/Story/STIStory_310849.html | accessdate = June 24, 2009 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081207012201/http://www.straitstimes.com/Breaking%2BNews/Singapore/Story/STIStory_310849.html | archivedate=December 7, 2008 }}</ref>
In October 2011, the Northview Baptist Church in [[Hillsboro, Ohio]] gave out copies of the Chick tract ''Mean Momma''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chick.com/reading/tracts/1068/1068_01.asp |title=Mean Momma, Chick Publications |publisher=Chick.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-21}}</ref> along with candy at [[Halloween]].<ref>''Mean Momma'' tells the story of Petunia Parker, hated by the town for her prior actions and her delinquent raising of her three sons; she scornfully rejects the church and refuses to fear God, only to have all three children die. The tract shows a gruesome detail of one child [[suicide by hanging|hanging himself]], while a caption quotes that "the Lord gave, and the Lord hath taken away" while showing a tornado hitting her house, killing her only remaining child (the first died in a car crash while attempting to elude law enforcement).</ref> The church received complaints from parishioners, and its pastor apologized for issuing the tracts, saying that, "Our church does not endorse this type of extreme methodology that was represented in this particular tract, and we can assure you that we will not let this happen again ... our church is a loving church that loves souls and wants to do all we can in our community to help as well as spread and share the Gospel message of Christ."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wnewsj.com/Main.asp?SectionID=49&SubSectionID=156&ArticleID=194019|title=Pastor apologizes for pamphlet handed out to trick-or-treaters|date=4 November 2011|website=archive.org|accessdate=16 May 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111104062748/http://wnewsj.com/Main.asp?SectionID=49&SubSectionID=156&ArticleID=194019|archivedate=4 November 2011|df=}}</ref>
In 2014, the Chick tract ''Unforgiven''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chick.com/reading/tracts/1043/1043_01.asp|title= Unforgiven |website=Chick Publications |date=2007 |accessdate=Jan 5, 2017}}</ref> was distributed by Bible Baptist Church in [[Garden City, Roanoke, Virginia]] and drew outrage from the area's Muslim community. The tract tells the story of an African-American man who, while in prison, is coerced into joining the Islamic faith and changes his name to Muhammad. Upon his release he threatens his Christian grandmother. Hussain Al-Shiblawi, a local man, told [[WDBJ-TV]] that he gets pamphlets from the church every Sunday and that they are typically inspirational, but that this one was different. "It basically indicated that the people are violent, the religion itself is violent, and the facts in here are not true," he said. "It shows him trying to kill his mother saying, 'If you weren't my grandma, I’d kill you where you stand, Allahu Akbar.{{'"}} In one scene, the grandmother begs Lamont to return to the Christian faith, telling him he will "die in [his] sins" and be unforgiven by God if he does not. But the young man is not swayed by her pleas. "I choose Muhammad! And I hate your Jesus, your Bible and you!" he screams. "Get out of my house, you infidel!" Bible Baptist Church said the church did not write the tract and simply distributed it.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theblaze.com/stories/2014/06/12/i-choose-muhammad-the-fiery-christian-tract-that-has-some-muslims-up-in-arms |title='I Choose Muhammad!': The Fiery Christian Tract That Has Some Muslims Up in Arms |website=[[TheBlaze]] |date=Jun 12, 2014 |accessdate=January 5, 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

(2013) ''Evolution: What the Fossils Say and Why It Matters'' (Columbia University Press)
==Further reading== *{{cite book | last = Fowler | first = Robert | title = The World of Chick? | publisher = Last Gasp | location = San Francisco | year = 2001 | isbn = 0-86719-512-6 }} *{{cite book | last = Kuersteiner | first = Kurt | title = The Art of Jack Chick | publisher = Schiffer Publications Ltd. | location = Atglen, PA | year = 2004 | isbn = 0-7643-1892-6 }} *'Jesus was Not a Weak Fairy: Chick Tracts and the Visual Culture of Evangelical Fear', chapter in {{cite book | last = Bivins | first = Jason | title = Religion of Fear : the Politics of Horror in Conservative Evangelicalism | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = Oxford New York | year = 2008 | isbn = 978-0-19-534081-5 |pages=41–88}} *Colonel V. Doner ''Christian Jihad: Neo-Fundamentalists and the Polarization of America'' (Samizdat Creative, May 23, 2012)

{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Distinguish|China Film Group Corporation}} '''China Movie Channel''' ({{Zh|t=中國電影頻道|s=中国电影频道|hp=Zhōngguó diànyǐng píndào}}) is a [[trade name]] of what is literally translated as the "Film Satellite Channel Programme Production Centre" ({{Zh|t=電影衛星頻道節目製作中心|s=电影卫星频道节目制作中心|hp=Diànyǐng wèixīng píndào jiémù zhìzuò zhōngxīn}}), an agency at the Chinese Government's [[State Administration of Press, Publication, Radio, Film and Television]]. ==Businesses== ===Television channels=== ====Mainland China==== * [[CCTV-6]]: China Movie Channel provides programming to the channel. ====Overseas==== These channels bear the China Movie Channel name, but they differ from the mainland equivalent in scheduling. * China Movie Channel (Hong Kong) * China Movie Channel (North America) ===1905.com=== '''1905.com''' is an online [[streaming media|streaming service]] operated by China Movie Channel. It is named after the year 1905, when ''[[The Battle of Dingjunshan (film)|The Battle of Dingjunshan]]'' (the first Chinese language film) was released. It was originally hosted on the m1905.com domain, but it later moved to the current one. ===Original films=== ===Other=== China Movie Channel is one of the production partners of ''[[Transformers: Age of Extinction]]''.{{cite web|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2013/04/02/transformers-4-china/|title=Paramount co-producing 'Transformers 4' with Chinese company|last=Franich|first=Darren|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=April 2, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/transformers-4-film-china-star-432311|title='Transformers 4' to Film in China, Star Chinese Actors as Paramount Enters Co-Production Agreement|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|last=Zakarin|first=Jordan|date=April 2, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.screendaily.com/paramount-partners-with-china-on-transformers-4/5053525.article|title=Paramount partners with China on Transformers 4|last=Shackleton|first=Liz|work=[[Screen International]]|date=April 3, 2013}} ==CCTV-6== {{Infobox TV channel | name = CCTV-6 电影
China Movie Channel | logofile = CCTV-6电影.png | logocaption = Above: logo of CCTV-6. Below: logo of China Movie Channel. | logosize = 200px | logo2 = [[File:中国电影频道.png|160px]] | launch = January 1, 1996 | picture format =[[16:9]]/[[4:3]] ([[576i]], [[SDTV]])
[[16:9]] ([[1080i]], [[HDTV]]) | share = | share as of = | share source = | owner = [[State Administration of Press, Publication, Radio, Film and Television]] | former names = | web = [http://cctv.cntv.cn/cctv6/ CCTV-6]
[http://www.m1905.com/cctv6/ China Movie Channel] | country = [[People's Republic of China|China]] | terr serv 1 = CCTV Analog (PAl-D) | terr chan 1 = Channel 6 (SD) | terr serv 2 = CCTV Digital (MUX3) | terr chan 2 = Channel 6 (SD)/506(HD) | sat serv 1 = | sat chan 1 = | adsl serv 1 = [[Now TV (China)|Now TV]] '''(Hong Kong)''' | adsl chan 1 = Channel 134 | online serv 1 = CNTV Ai Bugu | online chan 1 = [http://bugu.cntv.cn/live_channel6/index.shtml CCTV-6] }} '''CCTV-6''' or '''China Movie Channel''' of the [[State Administration of Press, Publication, Radio, Film and Television]] in the People's Republic of China, is a television channel dedicated to movies. It airs [[CCTV New Year's Gala]] since February 18, 1996. ===Programs=== *World Film Report (世界电影之旅) * China Film Report (中国电影报道) *The Best （Jia Pian You Yue）(佳片有约) * Movie Weekly (光影周刊) * Golden Times (流金岁月) * Love Movie Series ("爱-电影"系列) === Type of films played === * 故事片, ''Narrative Film'' * 译制片, ''Translated Film'' * 专题片, ''Special Film'' === Film collaborations === *''[[Transformers: Age of Extinction]]'' (2014) (with [[Paramount Pictures]], [[Platinum Dunes]], and [[di Bonaventura Pictures]]) *''[[Mission: Impossible – Rogue Nation]]'' (2015) (with [[Bad Robot Productions]], [[Skydance Productions]], [[Cruise/Wagner Productions|TC Productions]], and [[Alibaba Pictures]]) ==See also== * [[China Movie Channel Media Awards]] ==References== ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150319154302/http://www.sarft.gov.cn/articles/2007/06/01/20070904104418530417.html Introduction page] at the [[State Administration of Press, Publication, Radio, Film and Television]] * {{URL|1905.com/}} * [http://tv.cctv.com/cctv6/index.shtml Official Site] {{zh icon}} {{CCTV}} [[Category:Government agencies of China]] [[Category:Cinema of China]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 1996]]

revision.text:
The '''Dance Music [[Hall of Fame]]''' was an organization established in 2003 to honor and remember significant contributors to the genre of [[dance music]]. It had its first inductions in 2004 but went inactive after the 2005 induction ceremony.
==History== The Dance Music Hall of Fame was created in 2003 when music industry veteran John Parker ([[Robbins Entertainment]]) thought that something needed to be done to honor the creators and innovators of [[dance music]]. He enlisted the help of Eddie O'Loughlin ([[Next Plateau Records]]) initially and then they brought [[Daniel Glass]] (Glassworks), [[Tom Silverman]] ([[Tommy Boy Records]]) & Brian Chin (noted dance music writer/historian) in to form the organization. The Dance Music Hall of Fame recognizes the contributions of those who have had a significant impact on the evolution and development of dance music and celebrates the history and significance of the genre.
Artists, Producers, Record, Remixer and DJs that helped to shape the dance music industry become eligible for induction 25 years after their first contribution or record release. Criteria include the influence and significance of the nominee's contributions to dance music. The Dance Music Hall Of Fame Board of Advisers was composed of dance music professionals, historians and journalists. When the nominees were selected the ballots were sent to an international voting committee of over 1,000 dance music experts. An awards ceremony announcing the inductees in the Dance Music Hall Of Fame would take place annually at a formal dinner event in New York.
Due to financial differences among the Board members, The Dance Music Hall of Fame ceased operations after its second ceremony in 2005.
===First board=== 2004 - Dance Music Hall of Fame (DMHoF) Board of Directors: Daniel Glass, Eddie O'Loughlin, John Parker, Tom Silverman.
2004 - Board of Advisers: [[Marty Angelo]], [[John "Jellybean" Benitez]], Joey Carvello, [[Mel Cheren]], Michael Ellis, [[Dimitri from Paris]], Tony Humphries, [[Frankie Knuckles]], Jurgen Korduletsch, Brad LeBeau, John Luongo, Guy Moot, Michael Paoletta, Vince Pellegrino, Cory Robbins, [[Pete Tong]], Cary Vance, [[Louie Vega]], Pete Waterman, Judy Weinstein, Brian Chin.
== Inductees ==
===Artists=== * [[Chic (band)|Chic]] (2005) * [[Sylvester James|Sylvester]] (2005) * [[Gloria Gaynor]] (2005) * [[Bee Gees]] (2004)<ref name=bbc>{{cite news|title=Disco stars to enter Hall of Fame|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/3627796.stm|date=4 September 2004|accessdate=2010-07-13|work=BBC News}}</ref> * [[Donna Summer]] (2004)<ref name=bbc/> * [[Barry White]] (2004)
===Records=== * "[[Disco Inferno (The Trammps album)|Disco Inferno]]" - [[The Trammps]] (2005) * "[[Good Times (Chic song)|Good Times]]" - [[Chic (band)|Chic]] (2005) * "[[Got to Be Real]]" - [[Cheryl Lynn]] (2005) * "[[Stayin' Alive]]" - [[Bee Gees]] (2005) * "[[I Will Survive]]" - [[Gloria Gaynor]] (2005) * "[[I Feel Love]]" - [[Donna Summer]] (2004) * "[[Don't Leave Me This Way]]" - [[Thelma Houston]] (2004)<ref name=bbc/> * "Love Is the Message" - [[MFSB]] (2004) * "[[You Make Me Feel (Mighty Real)]]" - [[Sylvester James|Sylvester]] (2004) * "[[Shame (Evelyn King song)|Shame]]" - [[Evelyn "Champagne" King]] (2004)<ref name=bbc/>
===Producers=== * [[Bernard Edwards]] (2005) * [[Kenny Gamble]] (2005) * [[Nile Rodgers]] (2005) * [[Leon Huff]] (2005) * [[Quincy Jones]] (2005) * [[Pete Bellotte]] (2004)<ref name=bbc/> * [[Giorgio Moroder]] (2004)<ref name=bbc/> * [[Bobby Orlando]] (2018)
===DJs=== * [[John "Jellybean" Benitez]] (2005) * [[Francois Kevorkian]] (2005) * [[Frankie Knuckles]] (2005) * [[Larry Levan]] (2004)<ref name=bbc/> * [[David Mancuso]] (2004) * [[Tee Scott]] (2004)
===Remixers=== * [[Francois Kevorkian]] (2005) * [[Tom Moulton]] (2004)
===The Board of Directors Award for Lifetime Achievement (Non-Performer)=== * ''Mel Cheren'' (2005) * ''[[Henry Stone]]'' (2004)
==See also== *[[National Museum of Dance and Hall of Fame]]

;Photos *[http://dancemusic.about.com/library/bb2k4/bldms2k4c.htm About.com Photos from 2004 DMHOF Dinner] *[https://archive.is/20130121134038/http://www.discomusic.com/101-more/3124_0_7_0_C/ DiscoMusic.com Photos from 2004 DMHOF Dinner] *[http://www.djspyder.com/dmhof2005.htm DJ Spyder's 2005 DMHOF Photos]
